supporting_text: The NAP underscores the need for an effective 'one health' approach involving coordination among numerous sectors and partners, including human and veterinary medicine, agriculture and the environment.
The NAP includes objectives such as improving AMR awareness and education, strengthening laboratory and surveillance, and optimizing antimicrobial use in human health.
The NAP includes strategies for optimizing antimicrobial use in animal health and establishing guidelines for the use of antimicrobials in food-producing animals.
The NAP includes actions related to environmental health, such as establishing laboratory capacity to monitor AMR in environmental samples and developing waste management systems.
The NAP includes strategies for optimizing antimicrobial use in agriculture and establishing regulations for the use of antimicrobials in food-producing animals.
The NAP outlines a monitoring and evaluation plan that includes regular reporting on progress towards implementation.
The NAP defines strategic priorities, key actions, responsibilities, timelines, and budget for AMR activities.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence or antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes provisions for budgeting and securing financing for the implementation of the strategic plan.
The NAP includes an assessment of investment requirements for the implementation of the strategic plan.
The NAP establishes an AMR national multi-sectoral coordinating group (NMCG) to oversee the implementation of the plan.
The NAP includes strategies for establishing regulations for the use of antimicrobials in both human and veterinary settings.
The NAP includes objectives to improve awareness and understanding of AMR through education and training in various sectors.
The NAP includes actions to develop communication strategies and engage stakeholders in public awareness campaigns about AMR.
The NAP emphasizes the need for international collaboration and capacities for AMR prevention and control.
The NAP includes strategies for strengthening laboratory capacity and establishing an integrated AMR surveillance system.
The NAP outlines the need for improved surveillance and laboratory capacity to monitor AMR.
The NAP includes strategies for reducing the incidence of infection through effective sanitation, hygiene, and infection prevention measures.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes strategies for regulating the use of antimicrobials and maintaining essential medicine lists.
The NAP includes provisions for establishing regulations to ensure the rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP emphasizes the need for international collaboration in research and development related to AMR.
